property.name: text
property.value:
Here, there is one solver for each sub-lattice, so that you can compare the analysis results from each single sub-lattice to the results from the product lattice.
Double click a solver, or Right click -> Resolve Concepts, to analyze the model. Right click -> Clear Concepts to remove the concept annotations. Right click -> Look inside to see each lattice and corresponding actor rules.

property.name: text
property.value:
This solver composes the sub-lattices into a product lattice. Additional rules are introduced. Right-click -> Open Model to see the product lattice and new rules.
Next, compare the performance of the product lattice solver to the individual solvers. Right click -> Set Highlight Colors to choose the sub-lattice to inherit colors from. (For example, Right click -> Set Highlight Colors -> constLattice will color the model with green for Constant and red for Nonconstant).
Double-click the solver, or Right click -> Resolve concepts, to analyze the model. You can also execute the model and the TesterDirector will call the solvers to analyze the model. The annotations from the last solver added to the model (in this case the product solver) will show. The TesterDirector is in test mode - if you would like to change the model please double-click on the TesterDirector and check the "trainingMode" box.
Right click -> Clear Concepts to remove the concept annotations.

property.name: text
property.value:
This small example shows the power of the product lattice solver.
The ConstSolver uses the rule that the concept on the Scale's input (Nonconstant from the Ramp actor) should be <= the concept on the output. Therefore the Scale's output resolves to Nonconstant.
The Observable solver uses the rule that the concept on the Scale's output (Observable from the Display actor) should be <= the concept on the input. (A way to think of it is that the Observable solver works in the "backwards" direction). Therefore the Scale's input resolves to Observable.
The AbstractInterpretation solver uses the rule that a multiply by zero operation produces a Zero concept on the output.
However, the product lattice solver can do better than the ConstSolver and ObservableSolver alone. It has two additional rules: 1) The output of a multiply by zero operation is Constant, and 2) The input of a multiply by zero operation is Unobservable. It knows that the Scale actor performs a multiply by zero from the AbstractInterpretation analysis. Therefore, it concludes that the Scale's input is Unobservable and the Scale's output is Constant.

property.name: text
property.value:
For comparison, here is an example where the product lattice solver produces the same results as the individual solvers.
Here, the input to the Scale actor is Constant, so the output is Constant.
The output to the Scale actor is Unobservable, so the input is Unobservable.
The input value is Positive, multiplied by a Positive value, so the output is Positive.

property.name: _trainedConceptRecordArray

entity.name: Ramp
entity.doc: Create a sequence of tokens with increasing value
